page.title: 06FORESTRY - DERWENT VALLEY
page.content: Most of the trees including Turkey oak, English oak, Douglas fir, Norwegian spruce, cedar, larch, yew, sycamore, beech, silver birch, and conifers are about 33 years old. There are many much older. About 60 trees are felled at a time. It is not a viable proposition to uproot the entire tree mainly because of the cost and type of terrain. The roots are sprayed to prevent growth of fungus. Replanting takes place in spring. Forestry workers find that rabbits are a menace, eating seedling trees and stripping bark from saplings. When felled, the first section of the trees is known as the 'saw log'. These are sent to a Durham firm and used to make garden sheds and also to supply the building trade.
